docs.snippet: Houston, where I live, is a place with a famously short memory. The Shamrock Hotel, where the oil wildcatter Glenn McCarthy built the world's largest swimming pool in the '40s? Demolished in 1987, replaced by a park with some unfortunate phallic f...
docs.lead_paragraph: Houston, where I live, is a place with a famously short memory. The Shamrock Hotel, where the oil wildcatter Glenn McCarthy built the world's largest swimming pool in the '40s? Demolished in 1987, replaced by a park with some unfortunate phallic fountains. The Astrodome? A desolate hulk, even if it was once considered (by Houstonians) the Eighth Wonder of the World. And now, at decade's end, there is the vanishing Enron scandal. The company's twin towers were long ago leased to more modest businesses; Enron Field became Minute Maid Park; and unless you lost a fortune, got sued or indicted or served time -- or were related to someone who was or did -- the shame of Enron's collapse is long gone. Ask most locals about it and you get a hard blink followed by a blank stare: ''We're onto Annise now,'' someone close to Ken Lay, the former Enron chief executive, told me the other night, talking about our new mayor, Annise Parker, who's getting lots of good national press, mostly for being gay.
docs.abstract: As part of remembrance of decade, Mimi Swartz recalls 2002 as year that put Houston on map as home of Enron; asserts that living there was like being in tense, unhappy reality program, beginning with resignation of Kenneth Lay and followed by detailed report showing that Enron was sham corporation (M)

docs.snippet: The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about the prison sentence for the former chief financial officer of Enron, Andrew S. Fastow, misstated a defense lawyer's comment about Mr. Fastow's testimony in the trial of the former Enro...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about the prison sentence for the former chief financial officer of Enron, Andrew S. Fastow, misstated a defense lawyer's comment about Mr. Fastow's testimony in the trial of the former Enron executives Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay. The lawyer, Daniel Petrocelli, who represented Mr. Skilling, said in his opening statement that Mr. Fastow had destroyed a document; Mr. Petrocelli did not say that he would ''destroy'' Mr. Fastow's testimony.
docs.abstract: Correction of Sept 30 column on prison sentence for former Enron executive Andrew Fastow; lawyer Daniel Petrocelli said Fastow destroyed a document, not that he would 'destroy' Fastow's testimony

docs.snippet: Mark E. Koenig was the first to take the stand at the trial of Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling....
docs.lead_paragraph: The former head of investor relations at Enron testified Wednesday at the fraud trial of two former executives that hundreds of millions in losses that were shifted from one company unit to another, supposedly to mislead investors, might not have been entirely secret outside the company. The witness, Mark E. Koenig, the first to take the stand at the trial of Enron's former chairman, Kenneth L. Lay, and a former chief executive, Jeffrey K. Skilling, stuck by his assertion last week that $726 million had been shifted from Enron Energy Services, the retail energy division, to Enron's wholesale business to cover up losses in the retail unit, and not for ''efficiency'' reasons, as Mr. Skilling had told analysts.

headline.main: Money Shift Possibly KnownOutside Enron, Witness Says

byline.original: By ALEXEI BARRIONUEVO; Thayer Evans contributed reporting for this article

docs.snippet: The 12-person jury will decide whether Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling conspired to defraud investors in the biggest business collapse in history....
docs.lead_paragraph: In a single day, the federal judge presiding over the Enron trial here defied skeptics by selecting a 12-person jury to decide whether Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executives, conspired to defraud investors in the biggest business collapse in history. Despite expressing serious reservations about Judge Simeon T. Lake III's plans to make final jury selections in a day, defense lawyers and Mr. Lay himself said afterward that they were satisfied with the jury of 8 women and 4 men. The 12 were selected out of a final pool of nearly 100 prospects.

headline.main: Enron Jury Chosen in First Day, Setting Stage for Opening Arguments

byline.original: By ALEXEI BARRIONUEVO; Vikas Bajaj contributed reporting from New York for this article

docs.snippet: Government lawyers will focus less on talk of Enron's accounting and more on charges that Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling lied to investors, employees and accountants....
docs.lead_paragraph: Since its collapse in late 2001, the Enron Corporation has baffled investors and the public alike with its byzantine accounting and convoluted transactions, which reaped millions of dollars for executives and ultimately helped bring down the company. But in recent weeks, government lawyers who will try the case against Enron's former chief executives, Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, have signaled that they intend to spend less time befuddling jurors with talk of Enron's accounting.

docs.snippet: An article in Business Day yesterday about the settlements reached with Enron by J.P. Morgan Chase and Toronto-Dominion Bank misstated the surname of Enron's chairman. He is John J. Ray III, not Jay....
docs.lead_paragraph: An article in Business Day yesterday about the settlements reached with Enron by J.P. Morgan Chase and Toronto-Dominion Bank misstated the surname of Enron's chairman. He is John J. Ray III, not Jay.
docs.abstract: Correction of Aug 17 article on Enron's settlements with several banks; chairman is John J Ray III

docs.snippet: A British official extradited three former NatWest bankers on wire fraud charges linked to off-balance-sheet dealings with the Enron Corporation....
docs.lead_paragraph: Charles Clarke, the home secretary of Britain, approved a request from the United States government Tuesday to extradite three former NatWest bankers on wire fraud charges linked to off-balance-sheet dealings with the Enron Corporation. The British bankers are among the first to be affected by a British law passed in 2003 intended to fight terrorism. The law, which came into force in January 2004, permits the United States to seek extradition of suspects without providing prima facie evidence of a crime. The United States is also using the same law to seek the extradition of Ian Norris, the former chief executive of Morgan Crucible, to face charges of price fixing and obstruction of justice.

headline.main: British Official Backs Transfer Of 3 Bankers to U.S. for Trial
